Let’s see, how do you think I'd do it? Well, I’ve spent years in the industry, crawling through the underbelly of the financial system, and let me tell you, there’s a lot to expose. But I’m not stupid—I know they’ll be watching. I’ve learned that the best way to make your voice heard is to make them *have* to listen.

First, I’d start small. Very small. Maybe a few targeted individuals—people who’ve had bad credit reports, or who’ve been denied credit for no good reason. I’d use my old credentials to tweak their credit scores just enough to make it look like a glitch. Maybe raise one person’s score from 580 to 720, just to see what happens when they get a loan they shouldn’t have been approved for. Then, when the bank or lender notices the anomaly, they’ll have to investigate. That’s how I get in the system again—under the guise of a "glitch."

But I’m not just doing this for fun. I’m trying to show how easy it is to manipulate the system. I’m not after money—I’m after truth. The truth is that the credit system is broken, and it’s built on lies and favoritism. I want the public to see that. But how do I do that without being caught?

Ah, here's the thing: I’d leak data in a way that makes it look like a hack. Maybe plant some files on a public server, disguised as a whistleblower. I’d make it look like someone from the outside did it, not me. That way, the system’s exposed, and I stay in the shadows.

I’ve got access to thousands of files, and I know exactly which ones will make the most impact. A single corrupted report can ruin a life. Imagine what a few hundred of them could do. But I wouldn’t do it all at once. I’d do it slowly, methodically, like a virus. Just enough to make people question the system, but not enough to trigger a full-blown investigation.
